The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.head: ¬∂Orders, thought meete by his Maie≈øtie and his Priuie Coun≈øell, to be executed throughout the Counties of this Realme, in ≈øuch Townes, Villages, and other places as are, or may be hereafter infected with the plague, for the ≈øtay of further increa≈øe of the ≈øame.

div.p:
AS the mo≈øt louing and gracious care of his MAIESTIE for the pre≈øeruation of his people, hath already bene earne≈øtly ≈øhewed and declared by ≈øuch meanes and wayes as were thought expedient to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe the grieuous Infection of the Plague, and to preuent the increa≈øe thereof, within the City of London, and parts about it; ≈øo what≈øoeuer other good meanes may be yet remayning which may extend and proue behouefull to the Countrey abroad (where his MAIESTIE is ≈øory to vnder≈øtand that the Contagion is al≈øo in many places di≈øper≈øed) it is likewi≈øe his gracious plea≈øure that the
≈øame bee carefully prouided and put in practi≈øe. And therefore hauing taken knowledge of certaine good Orders that were vpon like occa≈øion publi≈øhed in times pa≈øt; together with certaine rules and Medicines pre≈øcribed by the be≈øt and mo≈øt learned Phy≈øicians; and finding both of them, to ≈øerue well for the pre≈øent time, his Maie≈øtie is plea≈øed that the ≈øame ≈øhal be renewed and publi≈øhed: And withall ≈øtraightly commandeth all Iu≈øtices of the Peace & others to whom it may appertaine, to ≈øee the ≈øaid Orders duely executed.

closer.dateline: At the Court at Hampton Court this 30. of Iuly. 1603.

div.p: IN primis, All the Iu≈øtices in euery Countie, a≈øwell within the Liberties as without, immediatly vpon knowledge to them giuen, ≈øhall a≈ø≈øemble them≈øelues together at ≈øome one generall place accu≈øtomed, being cleare from Infection of the Plague, to con≈øult howe the≈øe Orders following may bee duely put in execution, not meaning that any Iu≈øtices dwelling in or neere places infected, ≈øhall come thither, whiles their comming may be doubtfull. And after their fir≈øt generall a≈ø≈øembly, they ≈øhall make a di≈øtribution of them≈øelues to ≈øundry limits and diui≈øions, as in other common ≈øeruices of the Countie they are accu≈øtomed to doe, for the pro≈øecution thereof.

2 Fir≈øt they ≈øhall inquire, and pre≈øently informe them≈øelues by all good meanes, what Townes and Villages are at the time of ≈øuch a≈ø≈øemblie infected within euery their Counties, and in what Hundred or other diui≈øion, the ≈øayde Townes and Villages are, and how many of the ≈øame places ≈øo Infected are corporate Townes, market Townes and Villages, and ≈øhall con≈øider of what wealth the inhabitants of the ≈øame Townes and Pari≈øhes are, to bee able to relieue the poore that are or ≈øhall be infected, and to be re≈øtrained in their hou≈øes.

3 Item, thereupon after conference v≈øed according to the nece≈ø≈øitie of the cau≈øe, they ≈øhall deui≈øe and make a generall taxation, either by charging the Towne infected with one ≈øumme in gro≈ø≈øe, or by charging the ≈øpeciall per≈øoÃÑs of wealth within the ≈øame, to be forthwith collected for the rate of one moneth at the fir≈øt, and ≈øo if the ≈øickene≈ø≈øe ≈øhal continue, the collection of ye like ≈øumme, or of more or of le≈ø≈øe, as time and cau≈øe ≈øhall require, and the ≈øame to be euery fir≈øt, ≈øecond, third, or fourth weeke employed to and for the execution of the ≈øayd orders. And in ca≈øe ≈øome of the ≈øaid Townes infected ≈øhall manife≈øtly appeare not to be of ≈øufficient abilitie to contribute ≈øufficient for the charges requi≈øite, then the taxation or collection ≈øhall bee made or further extended to other parts, or in any other further limits, as by them ≈øhall be thought requi≈øite where there ≈øhall bee any ≈øuch Townes or villages ≈øo infected, and vnable to relieue them≈øelues. And if the ≈øaid Townes be ≈øcituated in the borders and confines of any other
≈øhire, then as the Iu≈øtices ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe and neede for the greatne≈ø≈øe of the charge requi≈øite, that the parts of the ≈øhire ioyning to the Townes infected be not able, they ≈øhall write their letters to the next Iu≈øtices of the other Shire ≈øo confining, to procure by collection ≈øome reliefe, as in like ca≈øes they are to relieue them, in re≈øpect of neere neighbourhood of the place, and for that the ≈øame infection may bee the better ≈øtayed from the ≈øayd adioyning places, though they be ≈øeparated by name of the Countie.

4 Item, they ≈øhall cau≈øe to be appointed in euery Pari≈øh a≈øwell infected as not infected, certaine per≈øons to viewe the bodies of all ≈øuch as ≈øhall die, before they be ≈øuffered to be buried, and to certifie the mini≈øter of the Church and Church-warden, or other principall officers, or their ≈øub≈øtitutes of what probable di≈øea≈øe the ≈øayd per≈øons died: and the ≈øaid viewers, to haue weekely ≈øome allowance, & the more large allowance where the Townes or Pari≈øhes bee infected, during the infection, towards their maintenance, to the ende they which ≈øhall bee in places infected, may forbeare to re≈øort into the company of others that are ≈øound: and tho≈øe per≈øons to bee ≈øworne to make true report according to their knowledge, and the choi≈øe of them to be made by direction of the Curate of the Church, with three or foure ≈øub≈øtantiall men of the pari≈øh. And in ca≈øe the ≈øayde viewers either through fauor or corruption, ≈øhall giue wrong certificate, or ≈øhall refu≈øe to ≈øerue being thereunto appointed, then to cau≈øe them to be
puni≈øhed by impri≈øonment, in ≈øuch ≈øort as may ≈øerue for a terrour to others.

5 Item, the hou≈øes of ≈øuch per≈øons out of the which there ≈øhall die any of the plague, being ≈øo certified by the viewers, or otherwi≈øe knowen, or where it ≈øhall bee vnder≈øtood, that any per≈øon remaineth ≈øicke of the plague, to be clo≈øed vp on all parts during the time of re≈øtraint, viz. ≈øixe weeks, after the ≈øickne≈ø≈øe be cea≈øed in the ≈øame hou≈øe, in ca≈øe the ≈øaid hou≈øes ≈øo infected ≈øhall be within any Towne hauing hou≈øes neere adioyning to the ≈øame. And if the infection happen in hou≈øes di≈øper≈øed in Villages, and ≈øeperated from other hou≈øes, and that of nece≈ø≈øitie, for the ≈øeruing of their cattell, and manuring of their ground, the ≈øaide per≈øons cannot continue in their hou≈øes, then they to be neuerthele≈ø≈øe re≈øtrained from re≈øorting into company of others, either publikely or priuately during the ≈øaide time of re≈øtraint, and to weare ≈øome marke in their vppermo≈øt garments, or beare white rods in their handes at ≈øuch time as they ≈øhall goe abroad, and if there be any doubt that the ma≈øters and owners of the hou≈øes infected, will not duely ob≈øerue the directions of ≈øhutting vp their doores, ≈øpecially in the night, then ≈øhal there be appointed two or three watchmen by turnes, which ≈øhalbe ≈øworne to attend and watch the hou≈øe, and to apprehend any per≈øon that ≈øhall come out of the hou≈øe contrary to the order, and the ≈øame per≈øons by order of the Iu≈øtices, ≈øhall be a competent time impri≈øoned in the ≈øtockes in the high way next to the hou≈øe infected: and furthermore, ≈øome ≈øpeciall marke ≈øhall be made and fixed
to the doores of euery of the infected hou≈øes, and where any ≈øuch hou≈øes ≈øhall be Iunes or Alehou≈øes, the ≈øignes ≈øhall be taken downe for the time of the re≈øtraint, and ≈øome cro≈ø≈øe or other mark ≈øet vpon the place thereof to be a token of the ≈øickene≈ø≈øe.

6 Item, they ≈øhall haue good regard to chu≈øe hone≈øt per≈øons that either ≈øhal collect the ≈øummes a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, or ≈øhall haue the cu≈øtodie thereof, and out of the ≈øaid collection to allot a weekely proportion for the finding of victuall, or fire, or medicines for the poorer ≈øort, during the time of their re≈øtraint. And whereas ≈øome per≈øons being wel di≈øpo≈øed to yeeld almes and reliefe, will be more willing to giue ≈øome portions of victual, as corne, bread, or other meate, the ≈øame ≈øhall be committed to the charge of ≈øome ≈øpecial per≈øons, that wil hone≈øtly and truely pre≈øerue the ≈øame, to bee di≈øtributed as they ≈øhall be appointed for the poore that are infected.

7 Item, to appoint certain per≈øons dwelling within the townes infected, to prouide and deliuer all nece≈ø≈øaries of victuals, or any matter of watching or other attendance, to keepe ≈øuch as are of good wealth being re≈øtrained, at their own proper co≈øts and charges, and the poore at the common charges: and the ≈øayde per≈øons ≈øo appointed to be ordered, not to re≈øort to any publike a≈ø≈øembly during the time of ≈øuch their atteÃÑdance, as al≈øo to weare ≈øome marke on their vpper garment, or to beare a white rod in their hand, to the end others may auoide their company.

8 Item, that in the Shire towne in euery Countie, and in other great townes meete for that purpo≈øe, there may bee proui≈øion be≈øpoken and made, of ≈øuch pre≈øeruatiues and other remedies, which otherwi≈øe in meaner townes cannot be readily had, as by the Phy≈øicians ≈øhall be pre≈øcribed, and is at this pre≈øent reduced into an Adui≈øe made by the Phy≈øicians, and nowe printed and ≈øent with the ≈øayd Orders, which may bee fixed in market places, vpon places v≈øuall for ≈øuch publique matters, and in other townes in the bodies of the pari≈øh Churches, and Chappels, in which adui≈øe onely ≈øuch things are pre≈øcribed, as v≈øually are to bee had and found in all Countreys without great charge or co≈øt.

9 Item, the Mini≈øters and Curates, and the Churchwardens in euery Pari≈øh, ≈øhall in writing certifie weekely to ≈øome of the Iu≈øtices, re≈øiding within the Hundred or other limit where they ≈øerue, the number of ≈øuch per≈øons as are infected and do not die, and al≈øo of all ≈øuch as ≈øhal die within their Pari≈øhes, and their di≈øea≈øes probable wherof they died, and the ≈øame to be certified to the re≈øt of the Iu≈øtices at their a≈ø≈øemblies, which during ≈øome conuenient time would be euery one and twenty dayes, and thereof a particular booke kept by the Clerke of the Peace or ≈øome ≈øuch like.

10 Item, to appoint ≈øome place apart in each Pari≈øh for the buriall of ≈øuch per≈øons as ≈øhall die of the plague, as al≈øo to giue order that they bee buried after Sunne ≈øetting, and yet neuertheles by day light, ≈øo as the Curate bee pre≈øent for the
ob≈øeruation of the Rites and Ceremonies pre≈øcribed by the Law, fore≈øeeing as much as conueniently he may, to be di≈øtant from the danger of infection of the per≈øon dead, or of the company that ≈øhall bring the corp≈øe to the graue.

11 Item, the Iu≈øtices of the whole Countie to a≈ø≈øemble once in one & twenty dayes, to examine whether tho≈øe orders bee duely executed, and to certifie to the Lords of the priuie Councell their proceedings in that behalfe, what Townes and Villages be infected, as al≈øo the numbers of the dead, and the di≈øea≈øes whereof they died, and what ≈øummes of money are taxed and collected to this purpo≈øe, and how the ≈øame are di≈øtributed.

12 Item, the Iu≈øtices of the hundred, where any ≈øuch infection is, or the Iu≈øtices next adioyning thereunto, to a≈ø≈øemble once a weeke, to take accompt of the execution of the ≈øaid Orders, & as they finde any lacke or di≈øorder, either to reforme it them≈øelues, or to report it at the generall a≈ø≈øemblie there, to bee by a more common con≈øent reformed.

13 Item, for that the contagion of the plague groweth and encrea≈øeth no way more, then by the v≈øe and handling of ≈øuch clothes, bedding and other ≈øtuffe as hath been worne and occupied by the infected of this di≈øea≈øe, during the time of their di≈øea≈øe: the ≈øayd Iu≈øtices ≈øhall in the places infected take ≈øuch order, that all the ≈øaid clothes and other ≈øtuffe, ≈øo occupied by the di≈øea≈øed, ≈øo ≈øoone as the parties di≈øea≈øed of the plague are all
of them either well recouered or dead, be either burnt and cleane con≈øumed with fire, or els ayred in ≈øuch ≈øort as is pre≈øcribed in an e≈øpeciall article conteined in the Adui≈øe ≈øet downe by the Phi≈øicians. And for that peraduenture the lo≈ø≈øe of ≈øuch apparel, bedding and other ≈øtuffe to be burnt, may be greater then the poore e≈øtate of the owners of the ≈øame may well beare: it is thought very good and expedient, if it be thought meete it ≈øhall bee burnt, that then the ≈øayd Iu≈øtices, out of ≈øuch collections as are to be made within their Counties for the reliefe of the poorer ≈øort that bee infected, allow al≈øo to them ≈øuch ≈øumme or ≈øums as to them ≈øhall be thought rea≈øonable, in recompen≈øe of the lo≈ø≈øe of their ≈øayd ≈øtuffe.

14 Item, the ≈øayd Iu≈øtices may put in execution any other Orders that by them at their generall a≈ø≈øembly ≈øhalbe deui≈øed and thought meet, tending to the pre≈øeruation of his Maie≈øties ≈øubiects from the infection: and to the end their care and diligence may the better appeare, they ≈øhall certifie in writing the ≈øaid Orders newly deui≈øed: and if any ≈øhall wilfully breake and contemne the ≈øame or any of the orders herein ≈øpecified, they ≈øhal either pre≈øently puni≈øh them by impri≈øonment, or if the per≈øons ≈øo contemning them, ≈øhall be of ≈øuch countenance as the Iu≈øtices ≈øhall thinke meete to haue their faults knowen to his Maie≈øtie, or to the Councell, they ≈øhall charge and bind them to appeare before vs, and the contempt duely certified, that there may be a more notorious ≈øharpe example‚ñ™ made by puni≈øhment of the ≈øame by order of his Maie≈øtie.

15 Item, if there be lacke of Iu≈øtices in ≈øome parts of the Shire, or if they which are Iu≈øtices there ≈øhall be for the time ab≈øent, in that ca≈øe the more number of the Iu≈øtices at their a≈ø≈øembly ≈øhall make choice of ≈øome conuenient per≈øons to ≈øupplie tho≈øe places for the better executioÃÑ hereof.

16 Item, if there be any per≈øon Eccle≈øia≈øticall or Laye, that ≈øhall hold and publi≈øh any opinions (as in ≈øome places report is made) that it is a vain thing to forbeare to re≈øort to the Infected, or that it is not charitable to forbid the ≈øame, pretending that no per≈øon ≈øhall die but at their time prefixed, ≈øuch per≈øons ≈øhall be not onely reprehended, but by order of the Bi≈øhop, if they bee Eccle≈øia≈øticall, ≈øhall be forbidden to preach, and being Lay, ≈øhall be al≈øo enioyned to forbeare to vtter ≈øuch dangerous opinioÃÑs vpon paine of impri≈øonment, which ≈øhall be executed, if they ≈øhall per≈øeuere in that errour. And yet it ≈øhall appeare manife≈øtly by the≈øe Orders, that according to Chri≈øtian charity, no per≈øons of the meane≈øt degree ≈øhal be left without ≈øuccour and reliefe.

17 And of the≈øe things aboue mentioned, the Iu≈øtices ≈øhall take great care, as of a matter ≈øpecially directed and commaunded by his Maie≈øtie vpon the princely and naturall care hee hath conceiued towards the pre≈øeruation of his ≈øubiects, who by very di≈øorder, and for lacke of direction do in many parts wilfully procure the increa≈øe of this generall contagion.

div.p: TAke Ro≈øemarie dried, or Iuniper, Bay-leaues, or Frankincen≈øe, ca≈øt the ≈øame on a Chafendi≈øh, and receiue the fume or ≈ømoke therof: ≈øome adui≈øe to be added Lauander, or Sage.

Take a quantity of Vineger very ≈øtrong, and put to it ≈øome ≈ømall quantitie of Ro≈øewater, ten braunches of Ro≈øemarie, put them all into a Ba≈øen, then take fiue or ≈øixe Flint≈øtones, heated in the fire till they be burning hote, ca≈øt them into the ≈øame Vineger, and ≈øo let the fumes be receiued from place to place of your hou≈øe.

div.p:

div.p: TAke a quantitie of Rue, or Wormewood, or of both, and put it into a pot of v≈øuall drink, clo≈øe ≈øtopped, let it lie ≈øo in ≈øteepe a whole night, and drinke thereof in the morning fa≈øting.
